source.3ed1856c:
sum_winner=0
sum_loser=0

for i in range(0,len(data["Winner Pts"])):
    sum_winner=sum_winner+data["Winner Pts"][i]
    sum_loser=sum_loser+data["Loser Pts"][i]

winner_avg=sum_winner/len(data["Winner Pts"])
loser_avg=sum_loser/len(data["Winner Pts"])

print("Average winner points:",winner_avg,"\nAverage loser points:",loser_avg)

fig.show()

source.fc31d479: ## Determining and Sorting Teams Win and Lose Counts
source.e9a44b2a: # Introduction Before starting talking about the analysis, I wanted to say that I am not an American football guy but I tried to do some analysis about the super bowls. For guys that are in the same position as me, the super bowl is the final game of the whole season of the NFL. This analysis includes 54 super bowls (2021 is not included). Before starting thanks for checking out my notebook. 1. [Implementing and Adjusting Data](#1) 1. [Sorter and Swap Functions](#2) 1. [Determining and Sorting Teams Win and Lose Counts](#3) 1. [MVPs](#4) 1. [Superbowl Locations](#5) 1. [Conclusion](#6)
